_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions at 40 CFR 68 establish requirements for the safe storage and handling of hazardous chemicals used in large quantities.  These provisions, promulgated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), apply directly to an Anhydrous Ammonia System that is owned, operated and maintained by Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. in Reading, Pennsylvania.



Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. has a comprehensive accidental release prevention and emergency response program for the Anhydrous Ammonia System.  The program consists of engineering controls, written policies, process safety information documents, operation and maintenance manuals, and other supporting documentation.  This program is consistent with the facility's general commitment to public safety and complies in full with EPA's Chemical Accident Provisions at 40 CFR 68.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 



Prior to commencement of operations in 2002, Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. established a set of formal, written policies to meet the requirements of EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions regulations, (often referred to as "RMP regulations" by Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. employees).  These policies also meet the requirements of similar Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations set forth by the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR 1910.119. 



The Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. is committed to protecting its employees, the public, and the environment from any accidental releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities.  We implement safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to minimize the risks presented by hazardous materials used at our facilities. We work with local response and regional emergency management agencies to plan for rapid emergency response, to minimize the effects of a potential release and to notify the

public of any action necessary to ensure public protection.   



The facility's integrated "RMP/PSM Policies" are intended to protect the environment in accordance with EPA regulations and provide protection of employees in accordance with OSHA regulations.  For each program element, there is a statement of facility policy, references to locations of documentation showing compliance with the policy, and references to the specific regulations that apply to the policy.



The facility maintains the integrated RMP/PSM Policies and supporting documentation in a set of clearly labeled document binders.  The binders are on-file in the facility's document control room, where they are accessible to all employees at the site.  



The Facility and Regulated Substances Handled   



Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. is a combined-cycle electric generation plant that uses gas-fired combustion turbines to make electric power.  The facility produces enough electricity to meet the needs of more than 500,000 homes throughout the region.  



Nitrogen oxides are a by-product of the turbines' combustion process.  Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC.'s air permit imposes restrictions on the amount of nitrogen oxide that the plant can emit into the air.  The facility uses an Anhydrous Ammonia System to control these emissions.  The system works as follows. 



Specialized tanker trucks bring anhydrous ammonia onsite, where it is transferred to two 1,600 cubic foot (12,000 gallon)  tanks and stored as a pressurized liquid.  Ammonia vapor is drawn from the tanks through a sealed system and into a selective catalytic reduction system, where it is injected into the exhaust stream of the facility's combustion turbines.  There, nitrogen oxides in the exhaust react with the ammonia to create harmless nitrogen and water.  The quantity in the tank is administratively controlled to an 85% maximum fill volume.



Collectively, the ammonia storage system and the selective catalytic red

uction system constitute the Anhydrous Ammonia System.  The Anhydrous Ammonia System enables the facility to meet EPA's Lowest Achievable Emission Rate for nitrogen oxides.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 



Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. has a comprehensive accidental release prevention program for the Anhydrous Ammonia System.  The Anhydrous Ammonia System has a number of engineering controls to prevent accidental releases.  Multiple, redundant monitors of system temperature, pressure, and flow will automatically notify the control operators before a problem occurs.  Fail-safe interlocks can shut the system down without human intervention.  Multiple ammonia detectors can quickly detect a release and automatically trigger a water deluge system to knock down ammonia vapors.  The facility has been designed for safety, and uses best industry practices for the safe unloading, storage and use of ammonia.   



In addition to engineering controls, the program includes a wide array of administrative controls to ensure that the Anhydrous Ammonia System is properly operated and maintained.  As noted above, the administrative controls include written RMP/PSM policies.  The administrative controls also include a detailed analysis of process hazards, written operating procedures, employee training, contractor training, contractor evaluation procedures, management-of-change procedures, regular mechanical integrity inspections and compliance audits.  



Preventive and corrective maintenance activities on the Anhydrous Ammonia System are planned, scheduled, assigned and documented using a computerized maintenance management information system known as Maximo.  This work management tool provides documented evidence that the requirements of the management of change and mechanical integrity programs are implemented in full.  In addition, Maximo is used for procuring and tracking replacement parts for the Anhydrous Am

monia System, and this ensures that proper parts are ordered, received and kept in stock.



All tests and inspections on the Anhydrous Ammonia System are scheduled consistent with manufacturers' recommendations.  To the extent that inspections reveal wear and tear, best efforts are made to replace parts in-kind.  If this is not possible, then the management of change procedures ensure that (1) any changes in equipment are consistent with good engineering practice, (2) process safety information is updated accordingly, (3) all operations and maintenance procedures are edited as required, and (4) all affected personnel are notified of the change and receive proper training.

 

Additional controls are provided by a rigorous lockout/tagout program, confined space procedures, hot work procedures, hazardous work permits, fire prevention and control procedures and more.  Employees participate fully in the implementation of the accidental release prevention program.



Five-Year Accident History 



The Anhydrous Ammonia System at Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. commenced operations in July 2002.  There have been no incidents or accidents in the entire history of the System.



Emergency Response Program



Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. has a three-part emergency response program, consisting of  (1) SA-400 One Plan Emergency Response Procedures,  (2) Emergency Response Plan for Employees and On Call Managers, and  (3) Off-Site Emergency Response Plan.  



The SA-400 document provides separate sets of procedures for a variety of difference emergencies, including but not limited to chemical spills and releases.  Roles and responsibilities are documented for key personnel, such as the control room operator, facility coordinator, and response team members.  Instructions are provided for controlling the release (consistent with Hazwoper training), administering first aid, and contacting appropriate agency offices and for evacuating the facility, if necessary

.  



Like SA-400, the Emergency Response Plan for Employees and On Call Managers provides instructions for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases; documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures; and procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance.  Hazard information is provided for each on-site chemical subject to EPCRA-LEPC regulations. 



The Off-Site Emergency Response Plan described above was developed in a cooperative effort with the Local Emergency Planning Committee for the Emergency Planning District of Berks County to meet the requirements of 42 U.S.C. 11003.  SA-400 is fully consistent with the Off-Site Emergency Response Plan.  Likewise, the Emergency Response Plan for Employees and On Call Managers is integrated with the Off-Site Emergency Response Plan.



Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. works closely with local response personnel to plan for emergencies.  The Leesport Fire Department and the Berks County Emergency Management Agency have toured the site and trained with Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. personnel.  This is an annual coordination with local agencies.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



The Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC. strives to improve safety by continually evaluating procedures to implement safer practices, as well as having the RMP and PSM plan evaluated by a qualified external auditing party.  Suggestions made by the auditing groups to improve the RMP and PSM program are implemented every three years into the Ontelaunee Power Operating Company LLC.s' plans and procedures.
